item.title: Get 69 Capcom Retro Games For Only $20 For A Limited Time
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/get-69-capcom-retro-games-for-only-20-for-a-limited-time/1100-6529572/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Humble has launched an awesome new video game bundle geared toward retro enthusiasts. The Capcom Arcade Classics and Fighters Pack for PC is a treasure trove of some the best games from an era of coin-operated gaming. All told, this bundle includes 69 games for only $20, which breaks down to 29 cents per game.

Unlike many Humble Bundles, the Capcom retro bundle doesn't have tiers; it's an all-or-nothing collection of Steam games that's available to purchase until March 11. The bundle supports Children's Miracle Network Hospitals. As usual, you can donate more than the minimum $20 and adjust the ratio of your donation between the charity, the publisher, and Humble.

If the number of games included sounds abnormally high, that's because the bulk of the inclusions are technically paid DLC within Capcom's pair of Arcade Stadium collections. Capcom Arcade Stadium is a free download, but adding games to the platform requires cash. With this Humble Bundle, you'll get a key for Arcade Stadium and Arcade Stadium 2 that instantly unlocks a wide assortment of games.

Capcom Arcade Stadium is a well-curated collection of '80s and '90s arcade games, including both Mega Man arcade games, great shoot-'em-ups such as 1943, classic platformers like Strider, and numerous entries from Capcom's popular fighting game series. In addition to several versions of Street Fighter 2, you're also getting the brilliant trilogy of Street Fighter Alpha games as well as Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo. You'll also find multiple Darkstalkers games and Final Fight. Even better, you can see just how much of your muscle memory you've retained for these games thanks to the inclusion of online multiplayer (for select titles).

The Arcade Stadium collections allow you to recreate the look and feel of an arcade with custom backdrops and machines, and there are also numerous quality-of-life updates to make revisiting these games a little easier. These range from subtle technical upgrades to a focus on making these games look as authentic as possible with numerous filters.

Beyond the Capcom Arcade Stadium compilations, this bundle also includes copies of Ultra Street Fighter 4, Street Fighter 5: Champion Edition, Street Fighter 30th Anniversary Collection, and a 50% discount code for the newest--and one of the best--entries in the series, Street Fighter 6.

Capcom Arcade Classics and Fighters Pack

  • Street Fighter 5: Champion Edition
  • Street Fighter 30th Anniversary Collection
  • Capcom Arcade Stadium
  • Capcom Arcade Stadium 2
  • Street Fighter
  • Ultra Street Fighter 4
  • Street Fighter 2 Turbo
  • Hyper Street Fighter 2: Anniversary Edition
  • Street Fighter 2: Anniversary Edition
  • Street Fighter 2: Hyper Fighting
  • Street Fighter 2: The World Warrior
  • Street Fighter Alpha: Warrior's Dreams
  • Street Fighter Alpha 2
  • Street Fighter Alpha 3
  • Super Puzzle Fighter 2 Turbo
  • Super Gem Fighter Mini Mix
  • Mega Man: The Power Battle
  • Mega Man 2: The Power Fighters
  • Captain Commando
  • Final Fight
  • Warriors of Fate
  • Battle Circuit
  • Ghouls 'n Ghosts
  • Ghosts 'n Goblins
  • Bionic Commando
  • Strider
  • 1944: The Loop Master
  • 19XX - The War Against Destiny
  • 1943 Kai - Midway Kaisen
  • 1943 - The Battle of Midway
  • 1942
  • 1941 - Counter Attack
  • Progear
  • Giga Wing
  • Commando
  • Three Wonders
  • Vampire Savior: The Lord of Vampire
  • Darkstalkers: The Night Warriors
  • Night Warriors: Darkstalkers' Revenge
  • Cyberbots
  • Dynasty Wars
  • Knights of the Round
  • Magic Sword
  • The King of Dragons
  • Saturday Night Slam Monsters
  • Mega Twins
  • Black Tiger
  • SonSon
  • Tatakai no Banka
  • Tiger Road
  • Hissatsu Buraiken
  • Capcom Sports Club
  • Last Duel
  • Rally 2011 LED Storm
  • The Speed Rumbler
  • Varth: Operation Thunderstorm
  • Vulgus
  • Legendary Wings
  • Forgotten Worlds
  • Savage Bees
  • Carrier Airwing
  • Senjo no Okamill
  • Section Z
  • Eco Fighters
  • Hyper Dyne Side Arms
  • Block Block
  • Pnickies
  • Gun Smoke
  • Pirate Ship Higemaru
  • Powered Gear: Strategic Variant Armor Equipment
  • Street Fighter 6 50% discount coupon

Subscribing to Humble Choice this month will also get you eight PC games for just $12, and as usual, they're yours to keep forever once you've claimed them. Immortals of Aveum is the big draw this month, and you can also add several other games to your collection like Trepang 2, Griftlands, and more. Beyond that, Humble has a few more bundle deals that you can explore in the list below:

  • Better With a Friends: Co-op Adventures - Six items for $10
  • Deckbuilder Bonanza - Six items for $20
  • Pathfinder Kingmaker Bundle - 53 items for $45

Fanatical also has a great Capcom bundle

Humble isn't the only digital storefront with a Capcom-focused game bundle right now. Over at Fanatical, you can build your own bundle of modern and classic Capcom games for cheap. Part of Fanatical's most recent Bundlefest promotion, this offer lets you get two games for $13, three games for $19, or four games for $25. Eligible titles include Devil May Cry 5, Marvel vs. Capcom Infinite: Deluxe Edition, Resident Evil 7, and plenty of other hits. Some of the eligible items contain multiple games in one. For example, there's a Resident Evil and Resident Evil 0 Double Pack, both of the Mega Man X Legacy Collections, and Street Fighter 30th Anniversary Collection.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

item.title: Sony Didn't Pass On Dark Souls--From Software Just Passed On Sony
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/sony-didnt-pass-on-dark-souls-from-software-just-passed-on-sony/1100-6529577/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Choices have consequences. Unfortunately for Sony, one particular decision has led the company to missing out on a couple of the biggest franchises in gaming. The PlayStation team decided not to publish Demon's Souls globally in 2009, which led to a sour taste for the now-well-known studio From Software. That meant the developer looked elsewhere for a publisher with Dark Souls, according to former PlayStation boss Shuhei Yoshida.

VGC reports that Yoshida explained why Sony didn't publish Dark Souls while appearing on the Secret Symbols podcast. It wasn't because the PlayStation team wasn't interested, per Yoshida. "From Software was already working on the sequel [to Demon's Souls], but they were so disappointed with how PlayStation treated them, we wanted to work with them again but they passed on it," said Yoshida.

Elden Ring Nightreign Explores Exciting And Unexpected New Ground For From Software

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

For those unfamiliar, Atlus ended up publishing Demon's Souls in North America for PS3, while Bandai Namco handled similar duties in Europe. Sony reportedly passed on bringing the action-RPG to other worldwide markets because the PlayStation team didn't think it would appeal to the mass market. Ultimately, Demon's Souls ended up being GameSpot's game of the year in 2009.

Afterward, From Software partnered with Bandai Namco for the Dark Souls franchise, which spawned three games. From there, Bandai Namco has also worked with the developer on the critically acclaimed Elden Ring series, with Elden Ring Nightreign launching on May 30. So, in retrospect, Sony missed out on handling these two massive properties over the past 15 years.

However, Sony did team up with From Software again for the PS4 exclusive Bloodbourne. "We have huge respect for [From Software president Hidetaka] Miyazaki, and we were able to work with them again," Yoshida said. "Bloodborne is one of his best games."

Last month, Yoshida retired from Sony after 31 years with the company. Yoshida started his career as an accountant and rose up to be the Sony Interactive Entertainment worldwide president for over a decade before taking an indies job within the company.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
